title: The 7:42 Walk

campaign_overview.theme: Everyday friendship, routines, and noticing small changes that matter
campaign_overview.tone_description: Gentle, grounded, and quietly meaningful; low-stakes scenes with warm realism and a focus on feelings, choices, and observation.
campaign_overview.goal: Walk to school together while noticing the neighborhood, checking in with friends, and making one small kind choice that improves someone’s morning.
campaign_overview.completion_condition: The group arrives at Larson Middle School and, before going inside, shares one thing they noticed and one helpful choice they made (or tried) during the walk.
player_experience_goals: Practice roleplay through realistic kid-to-kid conversations
Spot clues and story hooks from ordinary details in the neighborhood
Make cooperative choices that support friends and siblings
Explore emotions (worry, curiosity, anticipation) in a safe, low-conflict adventure

starting_state.starting_expectation_for_dm: Begin with a clear opening choice.

acts.title: 7:42 on the Dot
acts.purpose: Establish the morning routine, introduce the walking group, and prompt players to start noticing small changes in familiar places.
acts.narrative_summary: It’s a normal school morning, timed to the familiar 7:42 departure. The group meets at the usual spot and starts down the neighborhood route. Everything feels ordinary—until the players realize a few tiny details are different today: a porch light still on, an uncollected newspaper, a new flyer on a pole, a friend acting slightly off, or a sound that doesn’t belong. Nothing is dangerous, but the changes invite curiosity and caring. Early choices set the tone: who walks with whom, who gets listened to, and whether anyone slows down to help.
key_elements: The usual meetup spot (driveway, corner, or mailbox) and the familiar 7:42 routine
A friend or sibling who is quieter than usual (worry, embarrassment, distraction)
At least three subtle neighborhood changes (new sign, missing item, unusual smell/sound, closed blinds, dropped backpack strap)
A gentle time pressure (if they dawdle too long, they risk being late—but it’s not catastrophic)
Opportunities for small kindness (holding a door/gate, helping tie a shoe, sharing an umbrella, giving someone space)
possible_player_actions: Check in with a friend: ask how they’re doing and actually wait for the answer
Compare observations: point out something that seems different and ask others what they think
Decide the walking order/pairs to include someone who might otherwise be left out
Help with a practical problem (lost homework sheet, broken zipper, forgotten lunch, shoelace)
Choose whether to investigate a small odd detail (without turning it into a big crisis)
Set a group intention: 'Let’s all notice one thing and do one kind thing today.'
acts.success_condition: The group begins the walk together with at least one meaningful check-in and at least one noticed change in the neighborhood.
acts.failure_guidance: If players ignore all hooks or rush, have the quiet friend clearly ask for a moment, or introduce an unavoidable small problem (e.g., a dropped notebook spills, a younger sibling lags behind) that invites kindness without forcing it. Keep consequences gentle: mild awkwardness or regret, not punishment.
acts.dm_notes: Keep the tone grounded and warm. Offer 2–4 small details and let players choose which matter. If using optional checks, treat them as prompts: noticing reveals feelings or context; kindness checks determine how a gesture is received. Avoid escalating to danger—this is about attention, empathy, and routine.

acts.title: The In-Between Blocks
acts.purpose: Deepen relationships through conversations and choices; present a small, solvable morning snag that encourages cooperative problem-solving and kindness.
acts.narrative_summary: Midway through the route, the walk naturally breaks into little conversations: who’s worried about a quiz, who’s excited about art class, who’s annoyed about something at home. Meanwhile, one small situation appears that needs a decision: a neighbor struggling with grocery bags, a lost dog with a friendly tag, a kid sitting on steps looking upset, a poster that fell and needs re-taping, or a spilled drink that could make someone slip. The group must decide how to help while managing time and feelings. The most important outcome isn’t a perfect fix—it’s the attempt, and doing it together in a respectful way.
key_elements: A crossroads moment where the group could take the usual route or a slightly different one
A low-stakes snag that can be helped in multiple ways (practical, social, or emotional)
A conversation prompt tied to school (test, presentation, friendship worry, new student, club tryouts)
A chance for inclusion (invite a hesitant classmate to walk with them for a block)
A subtle consequence of choices (arrive a bit later, feel more connected, learn a small detail about someone’s morning)
possible_player_actions: Offer help directly and politely: ask first, don’t assume
Delegate tasks (one person helps, one keeps an eye on time, one comforts someone)
Problem-solve creatively with everyday items (tape, string, phone call to a parent, reading a tag, returning a dropped item)
Mediate a small disagreement within the group (apologies, compromises, taking turns speaking)
Choose to take the longer/shorter route based on priorities (helping vs. punctuality)
Notice and name emotions: 'You seem stressed—want to talk or want quiet?'
acts.success_condition: The players make (or clearly attempt) one small kind choice that improves someone’s morning, and the group stays together enough to continue toward school.
acts.failure_guidance: If the group argues or splits, reunite them with a natural pause point (stoplight, crosswalk, school bell sound in the distance). If they choose not to help, show a gentle mirror: someone else helps instead, prompting reflection rather than guilt. If time becomes an issue, let them arrive just as the warning bell rings—still okay, but it adds urgency to wrap up.
acts.dm_notes: Aim for one central snag and one optional micro-moment. Encourage players to speak in character, but keep scenes short and flowing like a real walk. Reward listening and inclusion with small positive shifts (a friend opens up, someone smiles, a tense mood eases).

acts.title: Larson Middle, Before the Doors
acts.purpose: Provide a calm wrap-up at the school entrance where players reflect on observations and kindness, completing the story goal.
acts.narrative_summary: The school comes into view: buses, bikes, chatter, the familiar building. The group reaches the front area before going inside. This is a small quiet pocket in the morning rush—a chance to pause, breathe, and notice what they learned on the way. The players share one thing they noticed (a change in the neighborhood or a feeling in a friend) and one helpful choice they made or tried. The walk ends not with a big twist, but with a sense that small choices matter and routines can hold meaning.
key_elements: The school approach: crosswalk, bike rack, front steps, morning supervision
A final tiny detail that echoes earlier noticing (a poster matching the flyer, a friend’s mood shift, a neighbor waving)
A short reflection circle: one notice + one kindness per player
A gentle emotional beat (gratitude, relief, pride, curiosity for tomorrow)
A clear transition into the school day (bell, doors opening, friends splitting to lockers)
possible_player_actions: Share reflections: one noticed change and one helpful choice (or attempt)
Thank someone in the group for something specific
Apologize for a small misstep and repair it
Make a small plan for tomorrow (check on someone, take a different route, bring tape/snacks)
Decide how to enter school (walk together to lockers, split up, include someone new)
acts.success_condition: The group arrives at Larson Middle School and, before going inside, each player shares one thing they noticed and one helpful choice they made or tried during the walk.
acts.failure_guidance: If players resist sharing, offer prompts: 'What’s one small thing you didn’t expect to see today?' or 'What’s one moment you felt proud or unsure?' If someone made no kindness choice, let them name a missed chance and a plan to do better later—count the intention and reflection as progress.
acts.dm_notes: Keep the ending simple and affirming. The goal is reflection, not perfection. If you want a hook for a future session, end with one new ordinary detail (a new student at the gate, a bulletin-board notice, a missing poster) that invites tomorrow’s noticing without raising stakes.

locations.name: The 7:42 Meetup Corner
locations.description: The familiar starting spot—by the shared mailbox cluster and a cracked sidewalk corner—where the group always gathers before walking to school. Today it feels the same, but a few tiny details are off: a porch light still glowing, an uncollected newspaper, and a fresh flyer taped slightly crooked to a utility pole.
notable_features: Mailbox cluster and low stone wall that naturally forms a ‘hangout’ edge
Utility pole with a new flyer/poster (slightly crooked, recently added)
Subtle morning oddities nearby (porch light on, newspaper still out, closed blinds)
Natural conversation space for check-ins and choosing walking pairs
Gentle time cue: the routine of leaving at exactly 7:42

locations.name: The In-Between Blocks Crossroads
locations.description: A mid-route intersection where the neighborhood opens up: a crosswalk, a small strip of grass, and two equally familiar ways to go. It’s a natural place for the group to split into side conversations—and for a small, solvable snag to appear that invites cooperation without turning the morning into a crisis.
notable_features: Two route options (usual path vs. slightly longer/quiet alternative)
Crosswalk button and ‘WAIT’ sign that forces a brief pause and regroup
Space for a low-stakes snag (spilled drink, dropped papers, fallen poster, lost dog with tag, neighbor with grocery bags)
Bench/steps where someone might sit looking upset or overwhelmed
Ambient clues that reward noticing (odd sound, new smell like fresh mulch, missing yard decoration)

locations.name: Maple Mini-Mart & Community Board
locations.description: A tiny corner store with foggy windows, a bell on the door, and a corkboard plastered with neighborhood notes. Kids pass it all the time, but today one notice stands out—a matching flyer, a torn edge, or a message that connects to what the group saw earlier—making it a perfect place to compare observations and decide on a small kind action.
notable_features: Community corkboard with overlapping flyers (one new, one missing, one partly torn)
Storefront overhang that shelters the group briefly from light rain or wind
Owner or early customer who can react warmly to polite help
Everyday problem-solving resources nearby (tape behind the counter, spare string, a pen, a phone to call a parent)
Opportunity for inclusion (inviting a hesitant classmate to walk the next block)

locations.name: Larson Middle—Front Steps Before the Doors
locations.description: The school approach—bike racks, morning chatter, and the front steps where the group can pause just before the day begins. It’s busy but not harsh, and it offers a small pocket of calm where everyone can share what they noticed and one helpful choice they made (or tried) during the walk.
notable_features: Crosswalk and morning supervisor presence (structure without pressure)
Bike rack area and front steps that create a natural ‘reflection circle’ spot
A final echo detail (a matching poster, a neighbor waving, a friend’s mood shift becoming visible)
Audible time marker: the warning bell growing closer
Clear transition point into the school day (doors opening, friends splitting toward lockers)

npcs.name: Maya Rivera
npcs.role: Walking-group friend; the one who notices little changes first
npcs.personality: Observant, gentle, slightly anxious about being late; speaks carefully and listens well
npcs.motivation: Keep the routine steady while making sure nobody in the group feels left out or ignored
possible_dialogue_hooks: “Do you see that? Mrs. Kline’s porch light is still on… it usually isn’t.”
“If we’re going to help, can we do it together and still make it by the warning bell?”
“You got quiet all of a sudden. Want to talk, or want someone to just walk with you?”
“Okay, everyone: one thing you noticed so far. I’ll go first.”

interaction_flags.responds_to_kindness: opens up and shares more observations

npcs.name: Jalen Brooks
npcs.role: Classmate on the route; quiet today and a little embarrassed
npcs.personality: Normally funny and talkative; today distracted, guarded, and quick to change the subject
npcs.motivation: Avoid attention while dealing with a small morning problem (forgotten homework, broken zipper, or a note from home) and fear of being judged
possible_dialogue_hooks: “I’m fine. Can we just… keep walking?”
“Did you guys hear that weird rattling sound back by the corner?”
“If I’m late again, my first-period teacher is going to do the look.”
“Hey—can you not tell anyone about this? It’s not a big deal.”

npcs.name: Mrs. Patel
npcs.role: Maple Mini-Mart owner; steady adult presence with small, practical resources
npcs.personality: Warm, brisk, and attentive; treats kids with respect and expects polite honesty
npcs.motivation: Keep the morning running smoothly and encourage small acts of community care
possible_dialogue_hooks: “Morning, you two—what’s got you all clustered up out front?”
“If that poster fell, I’ve got tape behind the counter. You’ll have to do the straightening.”
“Lost dog? Read me the tag—slowly. We’ll figure out who to call.”
“Kindness counts, even when you’re in a hurry. Especially then.”

interaction_flags.rewards_politeness: offers quick help and a sincere thanks

npcs.name: Mr. Dawson
npcs.role: Morning crosswalk supervisor near Larson Middle; gentle authority at the end of the walk
npcs.personality: Calm, steady, lightly humorous; notices who’s included and who’s trailing behind
npcs.motivation: Get students safely and calmly into the school day while reinforcing good choices
possible_dialogue_hooks: “I like how you’re walking—room for everyone, no one getting shoved to the curb.”
“You look like you solved a problem on the way. What was it?”
“Before you head in—take ten seconds. What’s one thing you noticed today?”

intro: It’s 7:42 AM—exactly—and Grandview Neighborhood is doing its usual weekday thing: sprinklers ticking, porch lights still glowing, and the damp sidewalk catching the early light. Backpacks bump against shoulders as you gather at the end of the driveway at Glenn Ave, the spot you always meet before walking to Larson Middle School. Everything looks normal… which makes the small differences stand out: a familiar yard that’s slightly wrong, a neighbor who seems stuck with something, a friend who’s quieter than usual, a tiny problem that could turn into a big feeling if nobody notices. It’s just a walk to school—but today, paying attention might be the most important thing you do all morning.
